unnormalised: Delhi Jal Board Announces New Water Tariff Hike
normalised: Delhi Jal Board Announces New Water Tariff Hike

unnormalised: The Delhi Jal Board (DJB) has announced a revised water tariff structure, effective 1/07/2024, impacting residential and commercial consumers. The hike, approved in a board meeting last week, aims to cover rising operational costs and infrastructure maintenance. According to the DJB, the existing tariff hadn't been revised for 5 years, leading to financial strain.
normalised: The Delhi Jal Board (D-J-B) has announced a revised water tariff structure, effective first July two thousand and twenty four, impacting residential and commercial consumers. The hike, approved in a board meeting last week, aims to cover rising operational costs and infrastructure maintenance. According to the D-J-B, the existing tariff hadn't been revised for five years, leading to financial strain.

unnormalised: For households consuming up to 20,000 liters (20 KL) of water per month, the existing subsidy will continue. However, consumption exceeding 20KL will now be charged at a rate of ₹5 per 1000 liters (kiloliter) for the next 10KL. Consumption above 30KL but less than 40 KL will be billed at ₹7.5/KL, while usage above 40000 liters (40KL) will incur a charge of ₹10 per KL.
normalised: For households consuming up to twenty thousand liters (twenty kiloliter) of water per month, the existing subsidy will continue. However, consumption exceeding twenty kiloliter will now be charged at a rate of rupee five per one thousand liters (kiloliter) for the next ten kiloliter. Consumption above thirty kiloliter but less than forty kiloliter will be billed at rupee seven point five per kiloliter, while usage above forty thousand liters (forty kiloliter) will incur a charge of rupee ten per kiloliter.

unnormalised: Commercial establishments will face a steeper increase. The new commercial rate is set at ₹25 per KL for consumption up to 50KL. Usage between 50KL and 100KL will cost ₹35/KL, and any amount exceeding 100,000 liters (100KL) will be billed at ₹50 per KL. This differential pricing aims to encourage water conservation among larger consumers.
normalised: Commercial establishments will face a steeper increase. The new commercial rate is set at rupee twenty five per kiloliter for consumption up to fifty kiloliter. Usage between fifty kiloliter and one hundred kiloliter will cost rupee thirty five per kiloliter, and any amount exceeding one hundred thousand liters (one hundred kiloliter) will be billed at rupee fifty per kiloliter. This differential pricing aims to encourage water conservation among larger consumers.

unnormalised: The DJB estimates the average household water bill will increase by approximately 15-20%. This increase is projected to generate an additional revenue of ₹150 crore annually. These funds will be allocated towards upgrading water treatment plants, replacing aging pipelines, and improving water supply to underserved areas of the city. Consumers can view their detailed consumption history and revised bills online using their CRN number.
normalised: The D-J-B estimates the average household water bill will increase by approximately fifteen to twenty percent. This increase is projected to generate an additional revenue of rupee one hundred and fifty crore annually. These funds will be allocated towards upgrading water treatment plants, replacing aging pipelines, and improving water supply to underserved areas of the city. Consumers can view their detailed consumption history and revised bills online using their C-R-N number.

unnormalised: Citizens are encouraged to adopt water-saving practices to mitigate the impact of the tariff hike. Simple steps such as rainwater harvesting, fixing leaky taps, and using water-efficient appliances can significantly reduce water consumption. The DJB also plans to launch awareness campaigns to promote water conservation and responsible usage among residents.
